docs.title: 二次规划问题的类型（Types of QP problems）
Quadratic Program (QP) 与 Quadratically Constrained Quadratic Program (QCQP)
docs.text:
QP：二次规划

\[ egin{aligned} \min_x\ & rac{1}{2} oldsymbol{x}^T oldsymbol{Q} oldsymbol{x} + oldsymbol{c}^T oldsymbol{x} \ ext{s.t.}\ & oldsymbol{Bx}\leq oldsymbol{d} \ \ & oldsymbol{Ax} = oldsymbol{b} \end{aligned} \]

当 \( oldsymbol{Q} \succeq oldsymbol{O}\)（半正定）时，该 QP 为凸优化问题；当 \( oldsymbol{Q} = oldsymbol{O}\) 时就退化成线性规划（LP）。

QCQP：二次约束的二次规划

\[ egin{aligned} \min_x\ & rac{1}{2} oldsymbol{x}^T oldsymbol{Q} oldsymbol{x} + oldsymbol{c}^T oldsymbol{x} \ ext{s.t.}\ & rac{1}{2} oldsymbol{x}^T oldsymbol{Q}_i oldsymbol{x} + oldsymbol{c}_i^T oldsymbol{x}\leq oldsymbol{d} + oldsymbol{d}_i \leq 0, & i = 1, 2, \ldots, m \ \ & oldsymbol{Ax} = oldsymbol{b} \end{aligned} \]

当 \( oldsymbol{Q} \succeq oldsymbol{O}\) 且对所有 \(i\) 有 \( oldsymbol{Q}_i \succeq oldsymbol{O}\) 时，QCQP 是凸的；若每个 \( oldsymbol{Q}_i = oldsymbol{O}\)，则约束变成线性的，退化为 QP。

线性最小二乘回归（Linear least squares regression）

已知 \( oldsymbol{y} \in \mathbb{R}^n, oldsymbol{X} \in \mathbb{R}^{n imes p}\)，求参数 \( oldsymbol{w}\in \mathbb{R}^p\) 使

\[ \min_{ oldsymbol{w}}\Vert oldsymbol{y} - oldsymbol{Xw} \Vert_2^2 \]

从几何上看，就是把 \( oldsymbol{y}\) 正交投影到 \( oldsymbol{X}\) 的列空间 \(\operatorname{Range}( oldsymbol{X})\) 上。

记

\[ f( oldsymbol{w}) = oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{X}^T oldsymbol{Xw} - 2 oldsymbol{y}^T oldsymbol{Xw} + oldsymbol{y}^T oldsymbol{y}, \]

则 \( oldsymbol{w}^*\) 为最优解当且仅当

\[ abla f( oldsymbol{w}^*) = oldsymbol{0} \Leftrightarrow oldsymbol{X}^T oldsymbol{Xw} = oldsymbol{X}^T oldsymbol{y}. \]

当且仅当 \( oldsymbol{X}^T oldsymbol{X} \succ oldsymbol{O}\)（即 \( oldsymbol{X}\) 满列秩）时，\( oldsymbol{w}^*\) 唯一，并且

\[ oldsymbol{w}^* = ( oldsymbol{X}^T oldsymbol{X})^{-1} oldsymbol{X}^T oldsymbol{y}. \]

更一般地，对无约束二次函数

\[ f( oldsymbol{x}) = rac{1}{2} oldsymbol{x}^T oldsymbol{Q} oldsymbol{x} + oldsymbol{b}^T oldsymbol{x} \]

有

\[ abla f( oldsymbol{x}) = oldsymbol{Qx} + oldsymbol{b}. \]

于是 \( oldsymbol{x}^*\) 为最优点当且仅当

\[ abla f( oldsymbol{x}^*) = oldsymbol{Qx}^* + oldsymbol{b} = oldsymbol{0}. \]

根据矩阵 \( oldsymbol{Q}\) 的性质，可以分三种情形：

  • 情形 1：\( oldsymbol{Q}\succ oldsymbol{O}\)，则存在唯一解 \( oldsymbol{x}^* = - oldsymbol{Q}^{-1} oldsymbol{b}\)；
  • 情形 2：\(\det oldsymbol{Q} = 0\) 且 \( oldsymbol{b} \in \operatorname{Range}( oldsymbol{Q})\)，则最优解不唯一，存在无穷多解；
  • 情形 3：\(\det oldsymbol{Q} = 0\) 且 \( oldsymbol{b} otin \operatorname{Range}( oldsymbol{Q})\)，则无最优解且 \(f^* = -\infty\)。

为什么要看 \( oldsymbol{b}\) 与 \(\operatorname{Null}( oldsymbol{Q})\) 的关系？

利用线性代数中的基本结论

\[ \operatorname{Range}( oldsymbol{A}) = \operatorname{Null}( oldsymbol{A})^\perp, \]

可以把“是否可解”与 \( oldsymbol{b}\) 在 \( oldsymbol{Q}\) 的像空间与核空间中的投影关系联系起来。

一些典型的 QP / QCQP 模型

LOSSO（Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator）

已知 \( oldsymbol{y} \in \mathbb{R}^n, oldsymbol{X} \in \mathbb{R}^{n imes p}, t > 0\)，考虑约束最小二乘

\[ egin{aligned} \min_{ oldsymbol{w}}\ &\Vert oldsymbol{y} - oldsymbol{Xw} \Vert_2^2 \ ext{s.t.}\ &\Vert oldsymbol{w}\Vert_1 \leq t \end{aligned} \]

由于目标函数连续、可行域闭且有界，最优解一定存在；并且在合适条件下最优解唯一。

Ridge Regression

已知 \( oldsymbol{y} \in \mathbb{R}^n, oldsymbol{X} \in \mathbb{R}^{n imes p}, t > 0\)，

\[ egin{aligned} \min_{ oldsymbol{w}}\ &\Vert oldsymbol{y} - oldsymbol{Xw} \Vert_2^2 \ ext{s.t.}\ &\Vert oldsymbol{w}\Vert_2 \leq t \end{aligned} \]

这是一个标准的 QCQP。

SVM（支持向量机）

\[ egin{aligned} \min_{ oldsymbol{w}, b}\ & rac{1}{2}\Vert oldsymbol{w}\Vert^2 \ \mathrm{s.t.}\ & y_i( oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x}_i + b) \geq 1 \end{aligned} \]

这是一个具有线性约束的凸 QP。

docs.title: 几何规划（Geometric Program）
docs.text:
一个 monomial 是定义在正正象限 \(\mathbb{R}^n_{++} = \{ \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n : \boldsymbol{x} > \boldsymbol{0} \}\) 上的函数

\[ f(\boldsymbol{x}) = \gamma x_1^{a_1} x_2^{a_2} \cdots x_n^{a_n}, \]

其中 \(\gamma > 0\)，\(a_1, \ldots, a_n \in \mathbb{R}\)。

Posynomial 是若干 monomial 的和：

\[ f(\boldsymbol{x}) = \sum_{k=1}^{p} \gamma_k x_1^{a_{k1}} x_2^{a_{k2}} \cdots x_n^{a_{kn}}. \]

Geometric program（GP） 是形如

\[ \begin{aligned} \min_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ & f(\boldsymbol{x}) \\ \text{s.t.}\ & g_i(\boldsymbol{x}) \leq 1, & i = 1, \ldots, m \\ \ & h_j(\boldsymbol{x}) = 1, & j = 1, \ldots, r \end{aligned} \]

的优化问题，其中 \(f,\, g_i,\ i = 1,\ldots,m\) 为 posynomial，\(h_j,\ j = 1,\ldots,r\) 为 monomial。 约束 \(x > 0\) 通常作为 GP 的隐含条件。

docs.title: Convex Set
docs.text:
A set \(C \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}\) is \emph{convex} if the line segment between any two points \(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y} \in C\) lies entirely in \(C\), i.e.

\[ \boldsymbol{x} \in C,\; \boldsymbol{y} \in C,\; \theta \in [0,1] \;\Longrightarrow\; \theta\, \boldsymbol{x} + \bar{\theta}\, \boldsymbol{y} \in C,、 \]

where \(\bar{\theta} = 1 - \theta\)

For \(\theta \in [0, 1]\), \(\theta \boldsymbol{x} + \bar{\theta}\boldsymbol{y}\) is called a convex combination of \(\boldsymbol{x}\) and \(\boldsymbol{y}\) Similarly, \(\displaystyle \sum_{i = 1}^n \theta_i \boldsymbol{x}_i\) is a convex combination of \(\boldsymbol{x}_i\) when \(\displaystyle \sum_{i = 1}^n \theta_i = 1, \theta_i \geq 0\)

Examples of convex sets

Hyperplane: \(P = \{\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n\ | \ \boldsymbol{w}^T \boldsymbol{x} = b\}\) Halfspaces: \(H = \{\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n\ | \ \boldsymbol{w}^T \boldsymbol{x} \leq b\}\) Affine spaces: \(S = \{\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n\ | \ \boldsymbol{A}\boldsymbol{x} = \boldsymbol{b}\}\) Polyhedra: \(\displaystyle G = \bigcap H_i\) where \(H_i\) are halfspaces

docs.title: Properties of convex sets
docs.text:
Affine transformation preserves convexity

The image of a convex set under an affine transformation is convex

Convex combination

If \(C\) is convex, and \(\boldsymbol{x}_1, \boldsymbol{x}_2, \ldots, \boldsymbol{x}_m \in C\), then any convex combination

\[ \sum_{i=1}^{m} \theta_i\, \boldsymbol{x}_i \in C \]

docs.title: Convex Hull (凸包), Simplexes/Simplices (单纯形) and Cone (锥)
Convex Hull
docs.text:
The convex hull of a set \(S \in \mathbb{R}^n\), denoted \(\operatorname{conv}S\), is the smallest convex set containing \(S\).

\(\operatorname{conv} S\) is the set of all convex combinations of points in \(S\), i.e.

\[ \operatorname{conv} S = \left\{ \sum_{i=1}^{m} \theta_i \boldsymbol{x}_i : m \in \mathbb{N}, \boldsymbol{x}_i \in S, \theta_i \ge 0, i = 1,\ldots,m; \sum_{i=1}^{m} \theta_i = 1 \right\} \]

Proof

大概证明两个包含关系就好了，有缘补一下

Affinely independent points

\(m+1\) points \(\boldsymbol{x}_0, \boldsymbol{x}_1, \ldots, \boldsymbol{x}_m \in \mathbb{R}^n\) are affinely independent if \(\boldsymbol{x}_1 - \boldsymbol{x}_0,\boldsymbol{x}_2 - \boldsymbol{x}_0,\ldots,\boldsymbol{x}_m - \boldsymbol{x}_0\) are linearly independent

\(\boldsymbol{x}_0, \boldsymbol{x}_1, \ldots, \boldsymbol{x}_m \in \mathbb{R}^n\) are affinely independent if

\[ \sum c_i\boldsymbol{x}_i = \boldsymbol{0}, \sum c_i = 0 \Longrightarrow c_i = 0, i \in \{0, 1, \ldots, m\} \]

In \(\mathbb{R}^n\), the maximum number of affinely independent points is \(n + 1\)

docs.title: Simplexes
docs.text:
An \(m\)-dimensional \emph{simplex}, also called an \(m\)-simplex, is the convex hull of \(m+1\) affinely independent points.

Note

  • 0-simplexes are points
  • 1-simplexes are line segments
  • 2-simplexes are triangles
  • 3-simplexes are tetrahedra (四面体)

Examples

Probability \(n\)-simplex: \(\Delta_n = \{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathbb{R}^{n + 1}:\boldsymbol{\theta} \geq \boldsymbol{0}, \boldsymbol{1}^T \boldsymbol{\theta} = 1\}\) Unit \(n\)-simplex: \(\Delta_n' = \{\boldsymbol{\theta}' \in \mathbb{R}^{n}:\boldsymbol{\theta}' \geq \boldsymbol{0}, \boldsymbol{1}^T \boldsymbol{\theta}' \leq 1\}\)

The \(m\)-simplex in \(\mathbb{R}^{n}\) determined by affinely independent points \(\boldsymbol{x}_0, \boldsymbol{x}_1, \ldots, \boldsymbol{x}_m\) is the image of \(\Delta_m\) under a linear transformation:

\[ \boldsymbol{\theta} = \sum_{i=0}^{m} \theta_i \boldsymbol{e}_i \longmapsto \boldsymbol{x} = \sum_{i=0}^{m} \theta_i \boldsymbol{x}_i = \boldsymbol{X}\boldsymbol{\theta}, \]

where

\[ \boldsymbol{X} = [\boldsymbol{x}_0,\boldsymbol{x}_1,\ldots,\boldsymbol{x}_m] \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times (m+1)}, \boldsymbol{\theta} = (\theta_0,\theta_1,\ldots,\theta_m) \in \Delta_m \]

Also,

\[ \boldsymbol{x} = \sum_{i = 0}^m \theta_i \boldsymbol{x}_i = \boldsymbol{x_0} + \sum_{i = 1}^m \theta (\boldsymbol{x}_i - \boldsymbol{x}_0) \]

The simplex \(\operatorname{conv}\{\boldsymbol{x}_0, \ldots, \boldsymbol{x}_m\}\) is also the image of \(\Delta_m'\) under the affine transformation

\[ \boldsymbol{\theta}' \longmapsto \boldsymbol{x} = \boldsymbol{x}_0 + \boldsymbol{B}\boldsymbol{\theta}' \]

docs.title: Convex Cone
docs.text:
A set \(C\) is a cone if \(\theta \boldsymbol{x} \in C\) for every \(\boldsymbol{x} \in C\) and \(\theta \geq 0\). A convex cone is a cone that is convex.

A set \(C\) is a convex cone iff

\[ \boldsymbol{x}_1, \boldsymbol{x}_2 \in C, \theta_1, \theta_2 \geq 0 \Longrightarrow \theta_1 \boldsymbol{x}_1 + \theta_2 \boldsymbol{x}_2 \in C \]

i.e. \(C\) is closed under conic combination.

docs.title: Conic Hull
docs.text:
The conic hull of a set \(S\), denoted \(\operatorname{cone}S\), is the smallest convex cone containing \(S\).

\(\operatorname{cone} S\) is the set of all conic combinations of points in \(S\), i.e.

\[ \operatorname{cone} S = \left\{ \sum_{i=1}^{m} \theta_i \boldsymbol{x}_i : m \in \mathbb{N}, \boldsymbol{x}_i \in S, \theta_i \ge 0, i = 1,\ldots,m \right\} \]

Difference between "convex" and "conic"

Just the property of \(\sum \theta = 1\)

docs.title: Projection onto convex set
docs.text:
Given a set \(C \subset \mathbb{R}\), the distance between a point \(\boldsymbol{x}\) and \(C\) is

\[ \operatorname{dist}(\boldsymbol{x}, C) = \inf_{\boldsymbol{z} \in C}\Vert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{z}\Vert \]

If \(C\) is nonempty, closed and convex, then for any \(\boldsymbol{x}\), there is a unique \(\boldsymbol{\hat{x}}\) s.t.

\[ \operatorname{dist}(\boldsymbol{x}, C) = \Vert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{\hat{x}}\Vert \]

\(\boldsymbol{\hat{x}}\) is called the projection of \(\boldsymbol{x}\) onto \(C\) and denoted by \(\boldsymbol{\hat{x}} = \mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x})\)

\(\mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x}) = \boldsymbol{x}\) iff. \(\boldsymbol{x} \in C\)

Proof

Existence: Let \(\boldsymbol{z}_0 \in C\). Then \(\operatorname{dist}(\boldsymbol{x}, C) \le \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{z}_0 \rVert\). Let \(K = \{\boldsymbol{z} \in C : \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{z} \rVert \le \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{z}_0 \rVert\} = C \cap \overline{B}(\boldsymbol{x}, \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{z}_0 \rVert)\). Since \(\lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{z} \rVert\) is continuous in \(\boldsymbol{z}\) and \(K\) is compact, there exists \(\boldsymbol{\hat{x}} \in K\) such that \(\operatorname{dist}(\boldsymbol{x}, C) = \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{\hat{x}} \rVert\).

Uniqueness: Suppose \(\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_1, \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_2 \in C\) satisfy \(\operatorname{dist}(\boldsymbol{x}, C)= \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_1 \rVert= \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_2 \rVert\). Let \(\displaystyle\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_c = \frac{\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_1 + \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_2}{2} \in C\). So

\[ \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_c \rVert \geq \operatorname{dist}(\boldsymbol{x}, C) \]

By the parallelogram law,

\[ \lVert y + z \rVert^2 + \lVert y - z \rVert^2 = 2\lVert y \rVert^2 + 2\lVert z \rVert^2 \]

we obtain

\[ \lVert \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_1 - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_2 \rVert^2 = 4\operatorname{dist}^2(\boldsymbol{x}, C) - 4\lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_c \rVert^2 \le 0 \]

so \(\boldsymbol{\hat{x}}_1 = \boldsymbol{\hat{x}}_2\)

Given \(\hat{\boldsymbol{x}} \in C\), \(\hat{\boldsymbol{x}} = \mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x})\) iff

\[ \langle \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}},\, \boldsymbol{z} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}} \rangle \le 0, \quad \forall\, \boldsymbol{z} \in C \]

Proof

Note \(\hat{\boldsymbol{x}} + t(\boldsymbol{z} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}) \in C,\forall \boldsymbol{z}\in C,t\in[0,1]\)，then

\[ \begin{aligned} \hat{\boldsymbol{x}} = \mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x}) &\Leftrightarrow \|\boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}} - t(\boldsymbol{z} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}})\|^2 \geq \|\boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}\|^2, \\&\Leftrightarrow -2t\langle \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}},\, \boldsymbol{z} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}} \rangle + t^2 \|\boldsymbol{z} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}\|^2 \geq 0, \\ &\Leftrightarrow \langle \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}},\boldsymbol{z} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}} \rangle \leq 0, \end{aligned} \]

Corollary:

\[ \Vert\mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x}) - \mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x})\Vert \leq \Vert\boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{y}\Vert \]

For all \(\boldsymbol{x_0} \notin C\), there exists \(\boldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{R}^n \setminus \{\boldsymbol{0}\}\) s.t. (1)

  1. Let \(\boldsymbol{w} = \boldsymbol{x_0} - \mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x}_0)\).
\[ \sup_{\boldsymbol{x} \in C}\langle \boldsymbol{w}, \boldsymbol{x}\rangle < \langle \boldsymbol{w}, \boldsymbol{x_0}\rangle \]

docs.title: Supporting hyperplane
docs.text:
If \(C\) is a nonempty, convex set in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) and \(\boldsymbol{x}_0 \in \partial C\), then there exists \(\boldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{R}^n \setminus \{ \boldsymbol{0} \}\) such that

\[ \langle \boldsymbol{w}, \boldsymbol{x} \rangle \leq \langle \boldsymbol{w}, \boldsymbol{x}_0 \rangle, \quad \forall \boldsymbol{x} \in C \]

\(P = \{\boldsymbol{x} : \boldsymbol{w}^T \boldsymbol{x} = \boldsymbol{w}^T \boldsymbol{x}_0\}\) is called a supporting hyperplane to \(C\) at \(\boldsymbol{x}_0\).

Boundary, inner part and close hull

If \(C\) is convex, then \(\operatorname{int}C = \operatorname{int}\overline{C}\) and \(\partial C = \partial \overline{C}\)

Proof to be completed...

Proof

\(\boldsymbol{x}_0 \in \partial C \Rightarrow \boldsymbol{x}_0 \in \partial \overline{C}\) by the previous lemma. There exists a sequence \(\{\boldsymbol{x}_k\}\) s.t. \(\boldsymbol{x}_k \notin \overline{C}\) and \(\boldsymbol{x}_k \to \boldsymbol{x}_0\) as \(k \to \infty\) Also, there exists \(\boldsymbol{w}_k \ne \boldsymbol{0}\) s.t.

\[ \langle \boldsymbol{w}_k,\, \boldsymbol{x} \rangle < \langle \boldsymbol{w}_k,\, \boldsymbol{x}_k \rangle, \quad \forall \boldsymbol{x} \in C \]

WLOG, assume \(\lVert \boldsymbol{w}_k \rVert = 1\). By the Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem, \(\{\boldsymbol{w}_k\}\) has a convergent subsequence \(\boldsymbol{w}_{k_i} \to \boldsymbol{w}\) Taking the limit \(i \to \infty\) along the subsequence,

\[ \langle \boldsymbol{w}_{k_i}, \boldsymbol{x} \rangle < \langle \boldsymbol{w}_{k_i}, \boldsymbol{x}_{k_i} \rangle \;\Longrightarrow\; \langle \boldsymbol{w}, \boldsymbol{x} \rangle \le \langle \boldsymbol{w}, \boldsymbol{x}_0 \rangle \]

docs.title: Separating Hyperplane
docs.text:
If \(C_1, C_2\) are nonempty, convex sets in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) with \(C_1 \cap C_2 = \emptyset\), then \(C_1\) and \(C_2\) can be separated by a hyperplane, i.e. there exists \( oldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{R}^n \setminus \{ oldsymbol{0}\}\), \(b \in \mathbb{R}\) such that

\[ egin{aligned} oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x} \leq b, orall oldsymbol{x} \in C_1 \ oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x} \geq b, orall oldsymbol{x} \in C_2 \end{aligned} \]

\(P = \{ oldsymbol{x} : oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x} = b \}\) is called a separating hyperplane for \(C_1\) and \(C_2\). (1)

  1. Proof by find supporting hyperplane or the corollary of \(C_1 - C_2\)

Proof

It suffices to show there exists a \( oldsymbol{w} eq oldsymbol{0}\) s.t.

\[ oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x}_1 \leq oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x}_2, orall oldsymbol{x}_1 \in C_1, oldsymbol{x}_2 \in C_2 \]

and let \(\displaystyle b = \sup_{ oldsymbol{x}_1 \in C_1 } oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x}_1\). And it is equivalent to

\[ \langle oldsymbol{w}, oldsymbol{x} angle \leq 0, orall oldsymbol{x} \in C_1 - C_2 \]

Since \( oldsymbol{0} otin C = C_1 - C_2\), there are two cases: 1. \( oldsymbol{0} otin \overline{C}\), it is the corollary \(\displaystyle \sup_{ oldsymbol{x} \in C}\langle oldsymbol{w}, oldsymbol{x} angle < \langle oldsymbol{w}, oldsymbol{x_0} angle\) 2. \( oldsymbol{0} \in \partial C\), it is the supporting hyperplane theorem

docs.title: Farkas’ Lemma
docs.text: Given \(\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}\) and \(\boldsymbol{b} \in \mathbb{R}^{m}\), exactly one of the following sets is empty: 1. \(S_1 = \{ \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n : \boldsymbol{A}\boldsymbol{x} = \boldsymbol{b},\boldsymbol{x} \geq \boldsymbol{0} \}\) 2. \(S_2 = \{ \boldsymbol{y} \in \mathbb{R}^m :\boldsymbol{A}^{T}\boldsymbol{y} \leq \boldsymbol{0}, \boldsymbol{b}^{T}\boldsymbol{y}> 0 \}\)

docs.title: 凸集.zh
docs.text:
中文 English

阅读信息

756 字 7 分钟  本页总访问量 加载中...

大多数证明都比较直接，这里只记录结论和关键形式，不展开全部细节。

docs.title: 凸集（Convex Set）
docs.text:
集合 \(C \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}\) 称为 凸集，如果对任意两点 \(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y} \in C\)，连接它们的线段完全落在 \(C\) 中，即

\[ \boldsymbol{x} \in C,\; \boldsymbol{y} \in C,\; \theta \in [0,1] \;\Longrightarrow\; \theta\, \boldsymbol{x} + \bar{\theta}\, \boldsymbol{y} \in C, \]

其中 \(\bar{\theta} = 1 - \theta\)。

当 \(\theta \in [0, 1]\) 时，\(\theta \boldsymbol{x} + \bar{\theta}\boldsymbol{y}\) 称为 \(\boldsymbol{x}\) 与 \(\boldsymbol{y}\) 的 凸组合。 同理，当满足

\[ \sum_{i = 1}^n \theta_i = 1,\quad \theta_i \geq 0 \]

时，\(\displaystyle \sum_{i = 1}^n \theta_i \boldsymbol{x}_i\) 称为点 \(\boldsymbol{x}_i\) 的一个凸组合。

一些典型的凸集

超平面（Hyperplane）：\(P = \{\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n\mid \boldsymbol{w}^T \boldsymbol{x} = b\}\) 半空间（Halfspace）：\(H = \{\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n\mid \boldsymbol{w}^T \boldsymbol{x} \leq b\}\) 仿射子空间（Affine space）：\(S = \{\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n\mid \boldsymbol{A}\boldsymbol{x} = \boldsymbol{b}\}\) 多面体（Polyhedron）：\(\displaystyle G = \bigcap H_i\)，其中 \(H_i\) 为若干半空间。

docs.title: 凸集的一些性质（Properties of convex sets）
docs.text:
仿射变换保持凸性

凸集在任意仿射变换（affine transformation）下的像仍然是凸的。

凸组合封闭性

若 \(C\) 是凸集，且 \(\boldsymbol{x}_1, \boldsymbol{x}_2, \ldots, \boldsymbol{x}_m \in C\)，则任意凸组合

\[ \sum_{i=1}^{m} \theta_i\, \boldsymbol{x}_i \in C \]

同样属于 \(C\)。

docs.title: 凸包、单纯形与锥（Convex Hull, Simplex, Cone）
凸包（Convex Hull）
docs.text:
对集合 \(S \subset \mathbb{R}^n\)，其 凸包 记为 \(\operatorname{conv}S\)，是包含 \(S\) 的最小凸集。

更具体地，\(\operatorname{conv} S\) 就是 \(S\) 中所有点的凸组合所构成的集合，即

\[ \operatorname{conv} S = \left\{ \sum_{i=1}^{m} \theta_i \boldsymbol{x}_i : m \in \mathbb{N}, \boldsymbol{x}_i \in S, \theta_i \ge 0, i = 1,\ldots,m; \sum_{i=1}^{m} \theta_i = 1 \right\}. \]

证明思路

证明只需分别验证“所有凸组合构成的集合是凸的且包含 \(S\)”以及“任意包含 \(S\) 的凸集都必然包含这些凸组合”，从而得到最小性。

仿射无关点（Affinely independent points）

若 \(\boldsymbol{x}_0, \boldsymbol{x}_1, \ldots, \boldsymbol{x}_m \in \mathbb{R}^n\) 满足向量

\[ \boldsymbol{x}_1 - \boldsymbol{x}_0,\ \boldsymbol{x}_2 - \boldsymbol{x}_0,\ \ldots,\ \boldsymbol{x}_m - \boldsymbol{x}_0 \]

线性无关，则称这 \(m + 1\) 个点仿射无关。

等价地，\(\boldsymbol{x}_0, \boldsymbol{x}_1, \ldots, \boldsymbol{x}_m\) 仿射无关当且仅当

\[ \sum c_i\boldsymbol{x}_i = \boldsymbol{0},\ \sum c_i = 0 \Longrightarrow c_i = 0,\ i \in \{0, 1, \ldots, m\}. \]

在 \(\mathbb{R}^n\) 中，仿射无关点的个数最多为 \(n + 1\)。

docs.title: 单纯形（Simplex）
docs.text:
一个 \(m\) 维 单纯形（\(m\)-simplex）是 \(m + 1\) 个仿射无关点的凸包。

一些例子

  • 0-单纯形就是一个点；
  • 1-单纯形是线段；
  • 2-单纯形是三角形；
  • 3-单纯形是四面体（tetrahedron）。

简单的单纯形例子

概率单纯形（probability \(n\)-simplex）： \(\Delta_n = \{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathbb{R}^{n + 1}\mid\boldsymbol{\theta} \geq \boldsymbol{0}, \boldsymbol{1}^T \boldsymbol{\theta} = 1\}\) 单位单纯形（unit \(n\)-simplex）： \(\Delta_n' = \{\boldsymbol{\theta}' \in \mathbb{R}^{n}\mid\boldsymbol{\theta}' \geq \boldsymbol{0}, \boldsymbol{1}^T \boldsymbol{\theta}' \leq 1\}\)。

在 \(\mathbb{R}^{n}\) 中，由仿射无关点 \(\boldsymbol{x}_0, \boldsymbol{x}_1, \ldots, \boldsymbol{x}_m\) 确定的 \(m\) 维单纯形，可以看作是 \(\Delta_m\) 在某个线性映射下的像：

\[ \boldsymbol{\theta} = \sum_{i=0}^{m} \theta_i \boldsymbol{e}_i \longmapsto \boldsymbol{x} = \sum_{i=0}^{m} \theta_i \boldsymbol{x}_i = \boldsymbol{X}\boldsymbol{\theta}, \]

其中

\[ \boldsymbol{X} = [\boldsymbol{x}_0,\boldsymbol{x}_1,\ldots,\boldsymbol{x}_m] \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times (m+1)},\quad \boldsymbol{\theta} = (\theta_0,\theta_1,\ldots,\theta_m) \in \Delta_m. \]

也可以写成

\[ \boldsymbol{x} = \sum_{i = 0}^m \theta_i \boldsymbol{x}_i = \boldsymbol{x_0} + \sum_{i = 1}^m \theta (\boldsymbol{x}_i - \boldsymbol{x}_0). \]

同样，单纯形 \(\operatorname{conv}\{\boldsymbol{x}_0, \ldots, \boldsymbol{x}_m\}\) 也可以看作 \(\Delta_m'\) 在某个仿射变换下的像：

\[ \boldsymbol{\theta}' \longmapsto \boldsymbol{x} = \boldsymbol{x}_0 + \boldsymbol{B}\boldsymbol{\theta}'. \]

docs.title: 凸锥与锥包（Convex Cone and Conic Hull）
docs.text:
集合 \(C\) 称为一个 锥（cone），如果对任意 \(\boldsymbol{x} \in C\) 和 \(\theta \geq 0\)，都有 \(\theta \boldsymbol{x} \in C\)。 若 \(C\) 既是锥又是凸集，则称为 凸锥（convex cone）。

等价地，\(C\) 是凸锥当且仅当

\[ \boldsymbol{x}_1, \boldsymbol{x}_2 \in C,\ \theta_1, \theta_2 \geq 0 \Longrightarrow \theta_1 \boldsymbol{x}_1 + \theta_2 \boldsymbol{x}_2 \in C, \]

即 \(C\) 对所有 锥组合（conic combination） 封闭。

docs.title: 锥包（Conic Hull）
docs.text:
集合 \(S\) 的锥包记为 \(\operatorname{cone}S\)，是包含 \(S\) 的最小凸锥。

更具体地，\(\operatorname{cone} S\) 是 \(S\) 中所有点的锥组合所构成的集合，即

\[ \operatorname{cone} S = \left\{ \sum_{i=1}^{m} \theta_i \boldsymbol{x}_i : m \in \mathbb{N}, \boldsymbol{x}_i \in S, \theta_i \ge 0,\ i = 1,\ldots,m \right\}. \]

“Convex” 与 “conic” 的区别

凸组合要求系数非负且和为 1；锥组合只要求系数非负，不要求和为 1。

docs.title: 支撑与分离超平面（Supporting and Separating Hyperplanes）
到凸集的投影（Projection onto convex set）
docs.text:
给定集合 \(C \subset \mathbb{R}^n\)，点 \(\boldsymbol{x}\) 到集合 \(C\) 的距离定义为

\[ \operatorname{dist}(\boldsymbol{x}, C) = \inf_{\boldsymbol{z} \in C}\Vert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{z}\Vert. \]

若 \(C\) 非空、闭合且凸，则对任意 \(\boldsymbol{x}\)，都存在一个 唯一的 点 \(\boldsymbol{\hat{x}} \in C\) 满足

\[ \operatorname{dist}(\boldsymbol{x}, C) = \Vert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{\hat{x}}\Vert. \]

这个点 \(\boldsymbol{\hat{x}}\) 称为 \(\boldsymbol{x}\) 在 \(C\) 上的 投影，记为 \(\boldsymbol{\hat{x}} = \mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x})\)。 显然，\(\mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x}) = \boldsymbol{x}\) 当且仅当 \(\boldsymbol{x} \in C\)。

存在性与唯一性

存在性：任取 \(\boldsymbol{z}_0 \in C\)，则

\[ \operatorname{dist}(\boldsymbol{x}, C) \le \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{z}_0 \rVert. \]

令

\[ K = \{\boldsymbol{z} \in C : \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{z} \rVert \le \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{z}_0 \rVert\} = C \cap \overline{B}(\boldsymbol{x}, \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{z}_0 \rVert). \]

由于 \(\lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{z} \rVert\) 关于 \(\boldsymbol{z}\) 连续且 \(K\) 是紧集，在 \(K\) 上必然能取到最小值，即存在 \(\boldsymbol{\hat{x}} \in K\) 使得 \(\operatorname{dist}(\boldsymbol{x}, C) = \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{\hat{x}} \rVert\)。

唯一性：若 \(\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_1, \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_2 \in C\) 都达到最小距离，即

\[ \operatorname{dist}(\boldsymbol{x}, C)= \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_1 \rVert= \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_2 \rVert, \]

令 \(\displaystyle\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_c = \frac{\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_1 + \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_2}{2} \in C\)。由于 \(\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_c\) 也在 \(C\) 中，有

\[ \lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_c \rVert \geq \operatorname{dist}(\boldsymbol{x}, C). \]

由平行四边形恒等式

\[ \lVert y + z \rVert^2 + \lVert y - z \rVert^2 = 2\lVert y \rVert^2 + 2\lVert z \rVert^2 \]

可推出

\[ \lVert \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_1 - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_2 \rVert^2 = 4\operatorname{dist}^2(\boldsymbol{x}, C) - 4\lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_c \rVert^2 \le 0, \]

从而 \(\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_1 = \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_2\)。

对给定的 \(\hat{\boldsymbol{x}} \in C\)，投影 \(\hat{\boldsymbol{x}} = \mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x})\) 还可以通过下述性质来刻画：

\[ \langle \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}},\, \boldsymbol{z} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}} \rangle \le 0, \quad \forall\, \boldsymbol{z} \in C. \]

证明

注意对任意 \(\boldsymbol{z}\in C,t\in[0,1]\)，点

\[ \hat{\boldsymbol{x}} + t(\boldsymbol{z} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}) \in C, \]

于是

\[ \begin{aligned} \hat{\boldsymbol{x}} = \mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x}) &\Leftrightarrow \|\boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}} - t(\boldsymbol{z} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}})\|^2 \geq \|\boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}\|^2, \\ &\Leftrightarrow -2t\langle \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}},\, \boldsymbol{z} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}} \rangle + t^2 \|\boldsymbol{z} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}}\|^2 \geq 0, \\ &\Leftrightarrow \langle \boldsymbol{x} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}},\boldsymbol{z} - \hat{\boldsymbol{x}} \rangle \leq 0. \end{aligned} \]

由此可以得到一个推论：

\[ \Vert\mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x}) - \mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{y})\Vert \leq \Vert\boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{y}\Vert, \]

即投影算子是 1-Lipschitz 的。

此外，对任意 \(\boldsymbol{x_0} \notin C\)，存在非零向量 \(\boldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{R}^n \setminus \{\boldsymbol{0}\}\) 使得

\[ \sup_{\boldsymbol{x} \in C}\langle \boldsymbol{w}, \boldsymbol{x}\rangle < \langle \boldsymbol{w}, \boldsymbol{x_0}\rangle. \]

其中一个自然的选择是

\[ \boldsymbol{w} = \boldsymbol{x_0} - \mathcal{P}_C(\boldsymbol{x}_0). \]

docs.title: 支撑超平面（Supporting hyperplane）
docs.text:
若 \(C\) 是 \(\mathbb{R}^n\) 中的非空凸集，\(\boldsymbol{x}_0 \in \partial C\)，则存在向量 \(\boldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{R}^n \setminus \{ \boldsymbol{0} \}\)，使得

\[ \langle \boldsymbol{w}, \boldsymbol{x} \rangle \leq \langle \boldsymbol{w}, \boldsymbol{x}_0 \rangle, \quad \forall \boldsymbol{x} \in C. \]

此时

\[ P = \{\boldsymbol{x} : \boldsymbol{w}^T \boldsymbol{x} = \boldsymbol{w}^T \boldsymbol{x}_0\} \]

称为 \(C\) 在点 \(\boldsymbol{x}_0\) 处的 支撑超平面。

边界、内部与闭包

若 \(C\) 为凸集，则有 \(\operatorname{int}C = \operatorname{int}\overline{C}\) 且 \(\partial C = \partial \overline{C}\)。 证明可以基于支撑超平面定理与闭包的性质。

一个证明思路

由上一个结论可知 \(\boldsymbol{x}_0 \in \partial C \Rightarrow \boldsymbol{x}_0 \in \partial \overline{C}\)。 可以构造一列点 \(\{\boldsymbol{x}_k\}\)，满足 \(\boldsymbol{x}_k \notin \overline{C}\) 且 \(\boldsymbol{x}_k \to \boldsymbol{x}_0\)。 对每个 \(k\)，存在 \(\boldsymbol{w}_k \ne \boldsymbol{0}\) 满足

\[ \langle \boldsymbol{w}_k,\, \boldsymbol{x} \rangle < \langle \boldsymbol{w}_k,\, \boldsymbol{x}_k \rangle, \quad \forall \boldsymbol{x} \in C. \]

不妨设 \(\lVert \boldsymbol{w}_k \rVert = 1\)。 由 Bolzano-Weierstrass 定理，序列 \(\{\boldsymbol{w}_k\}\) 存在收敛子列 \(\boldsymbol{w}_{k_i} \to \boldsymbol{w}\)。 沿该子列取极限，可得

\[ \langle \boldsymbol{w}_{k_i}, \boldsymbol{x} \rangle < \langle \boldsymbol{w}_{k_i}, \boldsymbol{x}_{k_i} \rangle \;\Longrightarrow\; \langle \boldsymbol{w}, \boldsymbol{x} \rangle \le \langle \boldsymbol{w}, \boldsymbol{x}_0 \rangle, \]

从而得到支撑超平面。

docs.title: 分离超平面（Separating Hyperplane）
docs.text:
若 \(C_1, C_2\) 是 \(\mathbb{R}^n\) 中的两个非空凸集，且 \(C_1 \cap C_2 = \emptyset\)，则它们可以被某个超平面分离： 存在 \( oldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{R}^n \setminus \{ oldsymbol{0}\}\)、\(b \in \mathbb{R}\) 使得

\[ egin{aligned} oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x} \leq b, &\quad orall oldsymbol{x} \in C_1, \ oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x} \geq b, &\quad orall oldsymbol{x} \in C_2. \end{aligned} \]

此时

\[ P = \{ oldsymbol{x} : oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x} = b \} \]

称为 \(C_1\) 与 \(C_2\) 的一个 分离超平面。 一种理解方式是通过 \(C_1 - C_2\) 的支撑超平面来构造。

证明思路

只要证明存在 \( oldsymbol{w} eq oldsymbol{0}\) 使得

\[ oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x}_1 \leq oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x}_2,\quad orall oldsymbol{x}_1 \in C_1, oldsymbol{x}_2 \in C_2, \]

然后令

\[ b = \sup_{ oldsymbol{x}_1 \in C_1 } oldsymbol{w}^T oldsymbol{x}_1。 \]

这等价于要求

\[ \langle oldsymbol{w}, oldsymbol{x} angle \leq 0,\quad orall oldsymbol{x} \in C_1 - C_2. \]

记 \(C = C_1 - C_2\)。由于 \( oldsymbol{0} otin C\)，分两种情况： 1. 若 \( oldsymbol{0} otin \overline{C}\)，可以直接使用前面的投影推论； 2. 若 \( oldsymbol{0} \in \partial C\)，则由支撑超平面定理得到所需结论。

docs.title: Farkas 引理（Farkas’ Lemma）
docs.text:
给定矩阵 \(\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}\) 与向量 \(\boldsymbol{b} \in \mathbb{R}^{m}\)，下面两类线性系统中，恰好有且只有一个是不可行的：

  1. \(S_1 = \{ \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n : \boldsymbol{A}\boldsymbol{x} = \boldsymbol{b},\ \boldsymbol{x} \geq \boldsymbol{0} \}\)；
  2. \(S_2 = \{ \boldsymbol{y} \in \mathbb{R}^m :\boldsymbol{A}^{T}\boldsymbol{y} \leq \boldsymbol{0},\ \boldsymbol{b}^{T}\boldsymbol{y}> 0 \}\)。

docs.title: 限制条件下的梯度下降
docs.text:
阅读信息

1356 词 9 分钟  本页总访问量 加载中...

Can we apply gradient descent to a constrained problem? Sometimes it will be infeasible. So we gonna project it onto the feasible set \(\Omega\)!

docs.title: Projected gradient descent
docs.text:
The gradient descent step:

\[ oldsymbol{x}_{k + 1} = oldsymbol{x}_k - t oldsymbol{g}( oldsymbol{x}_k), \quad oldsymbol{g}( oldsymbol{x}) = rac{1}{t}\left( oldsymbol{x} - \mathcal{P}_\Omega ( oldsymbol{x} - t abla f( oldsymbol{x})) ight) \]

i.e. \(\displaystyle oldsymbol{x}_{k + 1} = \mathcal{P}_\Omega ( oldsymbol{x}_k - t abla f( oldsymbol{x}_k))\)

For convex \(f\) and \(\Omega\), \( oldsymbol{g}( oldsymbol{x}^*) = oldsymbol{0}\) iff. \( oldsymbol{x}^*\) is a minimum of \(f\) over \(\Omega\).

Proof

\[ egin{aligned} oldsymbol{g}( oldsymbol{x}^*) = oldsymbol{0} & \Longleftrightarrow oldsymbol{x}^* = \mathcal{P}_\Omega ( oldsymbol{x}^* - t abla f( oldsymbol{x}^*)) \ & \Longleftrightarrow \langle oldsymbol{x}^* - t abla f( oldsymbol{x}^*) - oldsymbol{x}^*, oldsymbol{z} - oldsymbol{x}^* angle \leq 0, \quad orall oldsymbol{z} \in \Omega \ & \Longleftrightarrow \lang abla f( oldsymbol{x}^*), oldsymbol{z} - oldsymbol{x}^* ang \geq 0, \quad orall oldsymbol{z} \in \Omega \ & \Longleftrightarrow oldsymbol{x}^* ext{ is the minimum}. \end{aligned} \]

docs.title: Box constraint
docs.text:
\(\Omega = \{\boldsymbol{x}\ |\ \boldsymbol{a} \leq \boldsymbol{x} \leq \boldsymbol{b}\}\), the projection:

\[ \begin{aligned} \min_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ &\frac{1}{2}\Vert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{y}\Vert^2 \\ \text{s.t.}\ & \boldsymbol{a} \leq \boldsymbol{x} \leq \boldsymbol{b} \end{aligned} \]

Easily \(\displaystyle \mathcal{P}_\Omega(\boldsymbol{x}) = \min\{\boldsymbol{b}, \max\{\boldsymbol{a}, \boldsymbol{y}\}\}\)

docs.title: Affine constraint
docs.text:
\[ \begin{aligned} \min_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ &\frac{1}{2}\Vert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{y}\Vert^2 \\ \text{s.t.}\ & \boldsymbol{Ax} = \boldsymbol{b} \end{aligned} \]

By Lagrange condition, there exists \(\boldsymbol{\lambda}\),

\[ \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{y} + \boldsymbol{A}^T\boldsymbol{\lambda} = \boldsymbol{0} \Longleftrightarrow \boldsymbol{x} = \boldsymbol{y} - \boldsymbol{A}^T\boldsymbol{\lambda} \]

plugin and solve, we can get

\[ \mathcal{P}_{\Omega}(\boldsymbol{y}) = \boldsymbol{y} - \boldsymbol{A}^T(\boldsymbol{AA}^T)^{-1}(\boldsymbol{Ay} - \boldsymbol{b}) \]

docs.title: \(l_2\) Ball
docs.text:
\[ \begin{aligned} \min_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ &\frac{1}{2}\Vert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{y}\Vert^2 \\ \text{s.t.}\ & \Vert \boldsymbol{x} \Vert_2^2 \leq r^2 \end{aligned} \]

By KKT condition, there exists \(\mu \geq 0\),

\[ \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{y} + 2\mu \boldsymbol{x} = 0 \Longleftrightarrow \boldsymbol{x} = \frac{1}{1 + 2\mu}\boldsymbol{y} \]

we can get

\[ \mathcal{P}_{\Omega}(\boldsymbol{y}) = \min \left\{1, \frac{r}{\Vert \boldsymbol{y}\Vert_2}\boldsymbol{y}\right\} \]

docs.title: Ellipsoids
docs.text:
\(\Omega = \{\boldsymbol{x}\ |\ \boldsymbol{x}^T\boldsymbol{Qx} \leq 1\}\) where \(\boldsymbol{Q} \succ \boldsymbol{O}\)

\[ \begin{aligned} \min_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ &\frac{1}{2}\Vert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{y}\Vert^2 \\ \text{s.t.}\ & \boldsymbol{x}^T\boldsymbol{Qx} \leq 1 \end{aligned} \]

By KKT conditions, there exists \(\mu \geq 0\),

\[ \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{y} + 2\mu \boldsymbol{Qx} = 0 \Longleftrightarrow \boldsymbol{x} = (\boldsymbol{I} + 2\mu\boldsymbol{Q})^{-1} \boldsymbol{y} \]

If \(\boldsymbol{y} \in \Omega\), then \(\mu = 0, \boldsymbol{x} = \boldsymbol{y}\). If \(\boldsymbol{y} \notin \Omega\), then \(\mu > 0\). Let \(\boldsymbol{Q} = \boldsymbol{U\Lambda U}^T\) and \(\boldsymbol{z} = \boldsymbol{U}^T\boldsymbol{y}\), we have the equation of \(\mu\):

\[ 1 = \boldsymbol{x}^T\boldsymbol{Qx} = \boldsymbol{y}^T(\boldsymbol{I} + 2\mu\boldsymbol{Q})^{-1}\boldsymbol{Q}(\boldsymbol{I} + 2\mu\boldsymbol{Q})^{-1}\boldsymbol{y} = \sum_{i = 1}^n \frac{\lambda_i z_i^2}{(1 + 2\mu \lambda_i)^2} \]

docs.title: \(l_1\) Ball
docs.text: To be completed...

docs.title: Convergence analysis
docs.text:
Let \(\Omega\) be a nonempty convex set and \(f\) an \(L\)-smooth convex function. \(\boldsymbol{x}^*\) is the minimum of \(f\) over \(\Omega\). The sequence produced by PGD with step size \(t \leq \dfrac{1}{L}\) satisfies \(f(\boldsymbol{x}_{k + 1}) \leq f(\boldsymbol{x}_k)\) and

\[ f(\boldsymbol{x}_k) - f(\boldsymbol{x}^*) \leq \frac{\Vert \boldsymbol{x}^* - \boldsymbol{x}_0\Vert^2}{2tk} \]

Proof

Let indicator \(I_\Omega\) by

\[ I_\Omega(\boldsymbol{x}) = \begin{cases} 0, & \quad \boldsymbol{x} \in \Omega \\ +\infty, & \quad \boldsymbol{x} \notin \Omega \end{cases} \]

Then

\[ \operatorname{prox}_{I_\Omega}(\boldsymbol{y}) = \arg \min_{\boldsymbol{x}}\frac{1}{2}\Vert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{y} \Vert^2 + I_\Omega (\boldsymbol{x}) = \arg \min_{\boldsymbol{x} \in \Omega}\frac{1}{2}\Vert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{y} \Vert^2 = \mathcal{P}_{\Omega}(\boldsymbol{y}) \]

Then

\[ \boldsymbol{x}_{k + 1} = \operatorname{prox}_{t_kI_\Omega}(\boldsymbol{x_k} - t_k\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x}_k)) \]

Then it is the same as proximal gradient descent!

docs.title: Newton's Method
docs.text:
In a QP:

\[ \begin{aligned} \min_x\ &\frac{1}{2}\boldsymbol{x}^T\boldsymbol{Q}\boldsymbol{x} + \boldsymbol{c}^T\boldsymbol{x} \\ \text{s.t.}\ \ &\boldsymbol{Ax} = \boldsymbol{b} \end{aligned} \]

the Lagrange condition can be written as

\[ \begin{pmatrix} \boldsymbol{Q} & \boldsymbol{A}^T \\ \boldsymbol{A} & \boldsymbol{O} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \boldsymbol{x}^* \\ \boldsymbol{\lambda}^* \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -\boldsymbol{g} \\ \boldsymbol{b} \end{pmatrix} \]

The coefficient matrix \(\boldsymbol{K} = \begin{pmatrix}\boldsymbol{Q} & \boldsymbol{A}^T \\\boldsymbol{A} & \boldsymbol{O}\end{pmatrix}\) is called the KKT matrix.

Nonsingularity of KKT matrix

The following conditions are equivalent:

\(\boldsymbol{K}\) is nonsingular QP has a unique minimum \(\boldsymbol{F}^T\boldsymbol{QF} \succ \boldsymbol{O}\) for any \(\boldsymbol{F} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times (n - k)}\) s.t. \(\operatorname{Range}(\boldsymbol{F}) = \operatorname{Null}(\boldsymbol{A})\), i.e. the columns of \(\boldsymbol{F}\) form a basis of \(\operatorname{Null}(\boldsymbol{A})\) \(\boldsymbol{Av} = \boldsymbol{0}, \boldsymbol{v} \neq \boldsymbol{0} \Longrightarrow \boldsymbol{v}^T\boldsymbol{Qv} > 0\) \(\operatorname{Null}(\boldsymbol{Q}) \cap \operatorname{Null}(\boldsymbol{A}) = \{\boldsymbol{0}\}\)

Proof

Hence \(\boldsymbol{A}\) is full rank, each \(\boldsymbol{x}^*\) corresponds to a unique \(\boldsymbol{\lambda}^*\) satisfying the Lagrange condition.

To be completed...

docs.title: Newton’s method with feasible start
docs.text:
Consider the convex problem with equality constraints,

\[ egin{aligned} \min_x\ &f( oldsymbol{x}) \ ext{s.t.}\ \ & oldsymbol{Ax} = oldsymbol{b} \end{aligned} \]

The Newton direction at \( oldsymbol{x}_k\) is the solution to the approximation

\[ egin{aligned} \min_x\ &\hat{f}( oldsymbol{x}_k + oldsymbol{v}) = f( oldsymbol{x}_k) + abla f( oldsymbol{x}_k)^T oldsymbol{v} + rac{1}{2} oldsymbol{v}^T abla^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_k) oldsymbol{v} \ ext{s.t.}\ \ & oldsymbol{A}( oldsymbol{x_k} + oldsymbol{v}) = oldsymbol{b} \end{aligned} \]

i.e.

\[ egin{pmatrix} abla^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_k) & oldsymbol{A}^T \ oldsymbol{A} & oldsymbol{O} \end{pmatrix} egin{pmatrix} oldsymbol{v}\ oldsymbol{\lambda} \end{pmatrix} = egin{pmatrix} - abla f( oldsymbol{x}_k) \ oldsymbol{0} \end{pmatrix} \]

Lamma

By the KKT condition, we have a critical equation

\[ abla f( oldsymbol{x}_k) + oldsymbol{A}^T oldsymbol{\lambda} = - abla^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_k) oldsymbol{v} \] \[ egin{aligned} oldsymbol{x} ext{ is the minimal}& \Longleftrightarrow abla^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_k) oldsymbol{v} = 0 \ & \Longleftrightarrow oldsymbol{v} \in \operatorname{Null}( oldsymbol{A}) \cap \operatorname{Null}( abla^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_k)) = \{ oldsymbol{0}\} \ &\Longleftrightarrow oldsymbol{v} = oldsymbol{0} \end{aligned} \] \[ egin{aligned} & extbf{Initialization:}\ oldsymbol{x} \leftarrow oldsymbol{x}_0 \in \Omega \ ( ext{i.e. } A oldsymbol{x}_0= oldsymbol{b})\ & extbf{Repeat}\ &\quad ext{Compute Newton direction } oldsymbol{v} ext{ by solving}\ &\quad egin{pmatrix} abla^2 f( oldsymbol{x}) & A^T\ A & 0 \end{pmatrix} egin{pmatrix} oldsymbol{v}\ oldsymbol{\lambda} \end{pmatrix} = egin{pmatrix} - abla f( oldsymbol{x})\ oldsymbol{0} \end{pmatrix}\ &\quad t \leftarrow 1\ &\quad extbf{while } f( oldsymbol{x}+t oldsymbol{v}) > f( oldsymbol{x})+\alpha t abla f( oldsymbol{x})^T oldsymbol{v} \ extbf{do}\ &\qquad t \leftarrow eta t\ &\quad extbf{end while}\ &\quad oldsymbol{x} \leftarrow oldsymbol{x}+t oldsymbol{v}\ & extbf{Until } \| oldsymbol{v}\|\le\delta\ & extbf{Return } oldsymbol{x} \end{aligned} \]

docs.title: Convergence analysis
docs.text:
Let \( oldsymbol{F} \in \mathbb{R}^{n imes (n - k)}\) be a matrix whose columns are linearly independent solutions to \( oldsymbol{Av} = oldsymbol{0}\), then fix a feasible \( ilde{ oldsymbol{x}}\), every \( oldsymbol{x}\) has a unique representation of the form \( oldsymbol{x} = ilde{ oldsymbol{x}} + oldsymbol{Fz}\):

\[ \Omega = \{ oldsymbol{x}\ |\ oldsymbol{Ax} = oldsymbol{b}\} = \{ ilde{ oldsymbol{x}} + oldsymbol{Fz}\ |\ oldsymbol{z} \in \mathbb{R}^{n - k}\} \]

and the former problem reduces to unconstrained problem by \( oldsymbol{x} = ilde{ oldsymbol{x}}_0 + oldsymbol{Fz}\):

\[ egin{cases} \min_{ oldsymbol{x}} f( oldsymbol{x}) \ oldsymbol{Ax} = oldsymbol{b} \end{cases} \Longleftrightarrow \min_{ oldsymbol{z}} g( oldsymbol{z}) = f( ilde{ oldsymbol{x}} + oldsymbol{Fz}) \]

and accordingly \( oldsymbol{x}_k = ilde{ oldsymbol{x}} + oldsymbol{Fz}_k\)

Proof

We only need to show \( oldsymbol{x}_1 = ilde{ oldsymbol{x}} + oldsymbol{Fz}_1\) and reduction

Noting that \( oldsymbol{v}\) at \( oldsymbol{x}_0\) is the unique solution to

\[ egin{aligned} \min_{ oldsymbol{v}_0}\ & \hat{f}( oldsymbol{x}_0 + oldsymbol{v}) = f( oldsymbol{x}_0) + abla f( oldsymbol{x})^T oldsymbol{v} + rac{1}{2} oldsymbol{v}^T abla^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_0) oldsymbol{v} \ & oldsymbol{Av} = oldsymbol{0} \end{aligned} \]

and \( oldsymbol{u}\) is the unique solution of

\[ egin{aligned} \min_{ oldsymbol{v}_0}\ g( oldsymbol{z}_0 + oldsymbol{u}) &= g( oldsymbol{z}_0) + abla g( oldsymbol{z})^T oldsymbol{u} + rac{1}{2} oldsymbol{u}^T abla^2 g( oldsymbol{z}_0) oldsymbol{u} \ &= f( oldsymbol{x}_0) + abla f( oldsymbol{x})^T oldsymbol{Fu} + rac{1}{2} oldsymbol{u}^T oldsymbol{F}^T abla^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_0) oldsymbol{Fu} \end{aligned} \]

so \( oldsymbol{v} = oldsymbol{Fu}\)

So in the backtracking line search, the conditions \(t_0\) in \(f\) and \(g\) are the same! Then

\[ oldsymbol{x}_1 = oldsymbol{x}_0 + t_0 oldsymbol{v}_0 = ilde{ oldsymbol{x}} + oldsymbol{F}( oldsymbol{z}_0 + t_0 oldsymbol{u}_0) = ilde{ oldsymbol{x}} + oldsymbol{Fz}_1 \]

docs.title: Newton's method with infeasible start
docs.text: To be completed...

docs.title: Barrier method
docs.text:
In some cases of ICP:

\[ \begin{aligned} &\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}f(\boldsymbol{x}) \qquad (\text{ICP})\\ &\ \text{s.t.} \ \ \boldsymbol{Ax} = \boldsymbol{b} \\ & \quad \quad g_j(\boldsymbol{x}) \leq 0, \ j = 1, \ldots, m \end{aligned} \]

where \(f, g_j\) are smooth convex functions.

So far, we can solve some special cases - When projection onto the feasible set is easy, we can use projected gradient descent - When there are no inequality constraints, we can use Newton’s method or projected gradient descent

As before, we can reform ICP to

\[ \begin{aligned} &\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}f(\boldsymbol{x}) + I_{\bar{S}}(\boldsymbol{x})\\ &\ \text{s.t.} \ \ \boldsymbol{Ax} = \boldsymbol{b} \\ \end{aligned} \]

where \(\bar{S} = \{\boldsymbol{x}\ |\ g_j(\boldsymbol{x}) \leq 0,\ j = 1, \ldots, m\}\)

However, \(I(\boldsymbol{x})\) is not smooth. So we gonna approximate \(I(\boldsymbol{x})\) by so-called barrier functions.

docs.title: Barrier function
docs.text:
A continuous function \(B: S o \mathbb{R}\) is a barrier function for \(S\) if \(B( oldsymbol{x})\) as \( oldsymbol{x} \in S\) approaches the boundary of \(S\).

Common barrier functions

logarithmic barrier function

\[ B( oldsymbol{x}) = -\sum_{j = 1}^m \log (-g_j( oldsymbol{x})) \]

gradient

\[ abla B( oldsymbol{x}) = \sum_{j = 1}^m rac{1}{g_j(- oldsymbol{x})} abla g_j( oldsymbol{x}) \]

Hessian

\[ abla^2 B( oldsymbol{x}) = \sum_{j = 1}^m rac{1}{g_j^2(- oldsymbol{x})} abla g_j( oldsymbol{x})g_j( oldsymbol{x})^T + \sum_{j = 1}^m rac{1}{g_j(- oldsymbol{x})} abla^2 g_j( oldsymbol{x}) \]

inverse barrier function

\[ B( oldsymbol{x}) = -\sum_{j = 1}^m rac{1}{g_j( oldsymbol{x})} \]

Then we can approximate \(I_{ ar{S}}( oldsymbol{x})\) by \(\dfrac{1}{ au}B( oldsymbol{x})\)

\[ egin{aligned} &\min_{ oldsymbol{x}}F( oldsymbol{x}) = f( oldsymbol{x}) + rac{1}{ au}B( oldsymbol{x})\ &\ ext{s.t.} \ \ oldsymbol{Ax} = oldsymbol{b} \ \end{aligned} \]

Note

For it to be feasible, ICP should be strictly feasible, i.e. \(\{x \ |\ oldsymbol{Ax} = oldsymbol{b}, g_j( oldsymbol{x}) < 0\}\) is nonempty.

\(\operatorname{dom} f eq \mathbb{R}^n\), so always check whether \( oldsymbol{x}_k + t oldsymbol{d}_k \in \operatorname{dom} F\).

docs.title: Central path
docs.text: The solution \(\boldsymbol{x}^*(\tau)\) to it is called a central point, as \(\tau > 0\) varies, the curve \(\boldsymbol{x}^*(\tau)\) is called a central path if ICP

docs.title: Suboptimality gap of central point
docs.text:
\( oldsymbol{x}^*( au)\) is \(\dfrac{m}{ au}\)-suboptimal to ICP, i.e.

\[ f( oldsymbol{x}^*( au)) - f^* \leq rac{m}{ au} \]

Proof

The lagrangian is

\[ \mathcal{L}( oldsymbol{x}, oldsymbol{\lambda}, oldsymbol{\mu}) = f( oldsymbol{x}) + \sum_{j = 1}^m \underbrace{\mu_j}_{\geq 0}\underbrace{ g_j( oldsymbol{x})}_{\leq 0} + \underbrace{( oldsymbol{Ax} - oldsymbol{b})}_{=0} \lambda \leq f( oldsymbol{x}) \]

By the lagrange condition, there exists \( oldsymbol{\lambda}^*, oldsymbol{\mu}^*\),

\[ abla_{ oldsymbol{x}} \mathcal{L}( oldsymbol{x}^*( au), oldsymbol{\lambda}^*, oldsymbol{\mu}^*) = abla f( oldsymbol{x}^*) + \sum_{j = 1}^m \mu_j^* abla g( oldsymbol{x}^*( au)) + oldsymbol{A}^T oldsymbol{\lambda}^* = oldsymbol{0} \]

where \(\mu_j^* = -\dfrac{1}{ au g_j( oldsymbol{x}^*( au))} > 0\)

Noting that \( oldsymbol{x}^*( au)\) minimizes \(\mathcal{L}( oldsymbol{x}, oldsymbol{\lambda}^*, oldsymbol{\mu}^*)\), we have

\[ egin{aligned} f^* &= \inf_{ oldsymbol{x} \in X}f( oldsymbol{x}) \geq \inf_{ oldsymbol{x} \in X} \mathcal{L}( oldsymbol{x}, oldsymbol{\lambda}^*, oldsymbol{\mu}^*) \ &\geq \inf_{ oldsymbol{x} \in X} \mathcal{L}( oldsymbol{x}^*( au), oldsymbol{\lambda}^*, oldsymbol{\mu}^*) \ &= f( oldsymbol{x}^*( au)) + \sum_{j = 1}^m\underbrace{\mu_j^* g_j( oldsymbol{x}^*( au))}_{=- rac{1}{ au} ext{ by def.}} + \underbrace{( oldsymbol{Ax}^*( au) - oldsymbol{b})}_{=0} oldsymbol{\lambda}^* \ &= f( oldsymbol{x}^*) - rac{m}{ au} \end{aligned} \]

We call it the modified KKT conditions

docs.title: Derivative and Gradient
docs.text:
A function \(\boldsymbol{f} : S \subset \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m\) is differentiable at \(\boldsymbol{x}_0 \in \operatorname{int} S\), if there exists a matrix \(\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}\) such that

\[ \lim_{\Delta \boldsymbol{x} \to \boldsymbol{0}} \frac{ \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}_0 + \Delta \boldsymbol{x}) - \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}_0) - \boldsymbol{A}\,\Delta \boldsymbol{x} }{ \lVert \Delta \boldsymbol{x} \rVert } = 0. \]

i.e.

\[ \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}) = \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}_0) + \boldsymbol{A}(\boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{x}_0) + o(\lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{x}_0 \rVert). \]

Then we call the matrix \(\boldsymbol{A}\) the derivative of \(\boldsymbol{f}\) at \(\boldsymbol{x}_0\), i.e.

\[ \boldsymbol{f}'(\boldsymbol{x}_0) = D\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}_0) = \boldsymbol{A} \] \[ [D\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}_0)]_{ij} = \frac{\partial f_i(\boldsymbol{x_0})}{\partial x_j} \] \[ f_i(\boldsymbol{x}_0 + \Delta \boldsymbol{x}) = f_i(\boldsymbol{x}_0) + \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{\partial f_i(\boldsymbol{x}_0)}{\partial x_j}\, \Delta x_j + o(\lVert \Delta \boldsymbol{x} \rVert), \ i = 1, 2, \ldots, m \]

Gradient is the transpose of derivative for a real valued function \(\mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}\), which is a column vector.

\[ f'(\boldsymbol{x})\Delta \boldsymbol{x} = \langle \nabla f(\boldsymbol{x}), \boldsymbol{x} \rangle = \nabla f(\boldsymbol{x})^T \boldsymbol{x} \]

Some examples

(来自上学期的线代笔记啦)

\[ \begin{align} &\frac{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{x}^T \boldsymbol{y}}{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{x}} = \frac{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{y}^T \boldsymbol{x}}{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{x}} = \boldsymbol{y} & \quad \text{The inner product} \\ & \frac{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{x}^T \boldsymbol{Ax}}{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{x}} = (\boldsymbol{A} + \boldsymbol{A}^T)\boldsymbol{x} & \\ & \frac{\mathrm{d}\ \mathrm{tr}(\boldsymbol{B}^T\boldsymbol{A})}{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{A}} = \boldsymbol{B} & \\ & \frac{\mathrm{d}\ \mathrm{tr}(\boldsymbol{X}^T\boldsymbol{A}\boldsymbol{X})}{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{X}} = (\boldsymbol{A} + \boldsymbol{A}^T)\boldsymbol{X} & \\ & \frac{\mathrm{d}\det \boldsymbol{}}{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{A}} = \det \boldsymbol{A} (\boldsymbol{A}^{-1})^T \end{align} \]

docs.title: Secondary derivative
docs.text:
The second-order partial derivatives of \(f : S \subset \mathbb{R}^n o \mathbb{R}\) at \( oldsymbol{x}_0 \in \operatorname{int} S\) are

\[ rac{\partial^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_0)}{\partial x_i \partial x_j} \; riangleq\; \left. rac{\partial}{\partial x_i} \left( rac{\partial f(x)}{\partial x_j} ight) ight|_{x = oldsymbol{x}_0} \quad i,j = 1,2,\ldots,n \]

The Hessian (matrix) of \(f\) at \( oldsymbol{x}_0\), denoted by

\[ igl[ oldsymbol{ abla}^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_0) igr]_{ij} \;=\; rac{\partial^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_0)}{\partial x_i \partial x_j} \quad i,j = 1,2,\ldots,n \]

The second-order Taylor expansion for \(f : \mathbb{R}^n o \mathbb{R}\) takes the form

\[ f( oldsymbol{x} + oldsymbol{d}) = f( oldsymbol{x}) + abla f( oldsymbol{x})^{T} oldsymbol{d} + rac{1}{2} oldsymbol{d}^{T} abla^{2} f( oldsymbol{x}) oldsymbol{d} + o(\lVert oldsymbol{d} Vert^{2}) \]

docs.title: Bounds on quadratic forms
docs.text:
For a symmetric matrix \(\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}\),

\[ \lambda_{\min}\, \lVert \boldsymbol{x} \rVert_2^{2} \;\le\; \boldsymbol{x}^{T} \boldsymbol{A}\, \boldsymbol{x} \;\le\; \lambda_{\max}\, \lVert \boldsymbol{x} \rVert_2^{2}, \qquad \forall\, \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}, \]

where \(\lambda_{\max}\) and \(\lambda_{\min}\) are the largest and the smallest eigenvalues of \(\boldsymbol{A}\).

docs.title: Second-order sufficient condition
docs.text:
If \(f : \mathbb{R}^{n} \to \mathbb{R}\) is twice continuously differentiable and \(\boldsymbol{x}^{*}\) is a local minimum of \(f\), then its Hessian matrix \(\boldsymbol{\nabla}^{2} f(\boldsymbol{x}^{*})\) is positive semidefinite, i.e.

\[ \boldsymbol{d}^{T}\, \boldsymbol{\nabla}^{2} f(\boldsymbol{x}^{*})\, \boldsymbol{d} \;\ge\; 0, \quad \forall\, \boldsymbol{d} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \]

docs.title: 导数与梯度（Derivative and Gradient）
docs.text:
设函数 \(\boldsymbol{f} : S \subset \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m\)，若在点 \(\boldsymbol{x}_0 \in \operatorname{int} S\) 处存在矩阵 \(\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}\)，使得

\[ \lim_{\Delta \boldsymbol{x} \to \boldsymbol{0}} \frac{ \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}_0 + \Delta \boldsymbol{x}) - \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}_0) - \boldsymbol{A}\,\Delta \boldsymbol{x} }{ \lVert \Delta \boldsymbol{x} \rVert } = 0, \]

即

\[ \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}) = \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}_0) + \boldsymbol{A}(\boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{x}_0) + o(\lVert \boldsymbol{x} - \boldsymbol{x}_0 \rVert), \]

则称 \(\boldsymbol{f}\) 在 \(\boldsymbol{x}_0\) 处可微，并把这个矩阵 \(\boldsymbol{A}\) 称为 \(\boldsymbol{f}\) 在 \(\boldsymbol{x}_0\) 处的导数：

\[ \boldsymbol{f}'(\boldsymbol{x}_0) = D\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}_0) = \boldsymbol{A} \]

其中

\[ [D\boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}_0)]_{ij} = \frac{\partial f_i(\boldsymbol{x_0})}{\partial x_j} \]

并且对每一维分量都有

\[ f_i(\boldsymbol{x}_0 + \Delta \boldsymbol{x}) = f_i(\boldsymbol{x}_0) + \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{\partial f_i(\boldsymbol{x}_0)}{\partial x_j}\, \Delta x_j + o(\lVert \Delta \boldsymbol{x} \rVert), \ i = 1, 2, \ldots, m. \]

当 \(f:\mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}\) 是实值函数时，其导数 \(f'(\boldsymbol{x})\) 是行向量，其转置就是常见的 梯度（gradient），为列向量。

\[ f'(\boldsymbol{x})\Delta \boldsymbol{x} = \langle \nabla f(\boldsymbol{x}), \boldsymbol{x} \rangle = \nabla f(\boldsymbol{x})^T \boldsymbol{x} \]

几个常见的求导公式

（来自上学期线代笔记）

\[ \begin{align} &\frac{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{x}^T \boldsymbol{y}}{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{x}} = \frac{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{y}^T \boldsymbol{x}}{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{x}} = \boldsymbol{y} & \quad \text{内积的导数} \\ & \frac{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{x}^T \boldsymbol{Ax}}{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{x}} = (\boldsymbol{A} + \boldsymbol{A}^T)\boldsymbol{x} & \\ & \frac{\mathrm{d}\ \mathrm{tr}(\boldsymbol{B}^T\boldsymbol{A})}{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{A}} = \boldsymbol{B} & \\ & \frac{\mathrm{d}\ \mathrm{tr}(\boldsymbol{X}^T\boldsymbol{A}\boldsymbol{X})}{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{X}} = (\boldsymbol{A} + \boldsymbol{A}^T)\boldsymbol{X} & \\ & \frac{\mathrm{d}\det \boldsymbol{}}{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{A}} = \det \boldsymbol{A} (\boldsymbol{A}^{-1})^T \end{align} \]

docs.title: 二阶导数（Second-order derivative）
docs.text:
对函数 \(f : S \subset \mathbb{R}^n o \mathbb{R}\)，在 \( oldsymbol{x}_0 \in \operatorname{int} S\) 处的二阶偏导定义为

\[ rac{\partial^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_0)}{\partial x_i \partial x_j} \; riangleq\; \left. rac{\partial}{\partial x_i} \left( rac{\partial f(x)}{\partial x_j} ight) ight|_{x = oldsymbol{x}_0}, \quad i,j = 1,2,\ldots,n. \]

Hessian 矩阵 定义为

\[ igl[ oldsymbol{ abla}^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_0) igr]_{ij} \;=\; rac{\partial^2 f( oldsymbol{x}_0)}{\partial x_i \partial x_j}, \quad i,j = 1,2,\ldots,n. \]

对 \(f : \mathbb{R}^n o \mathbb{R}\)，其二阶泰勒展开可以写成

\[ f( oldsymbol{x} + oldsymbol{d}) = f( oldsymbol{x}) + abla f( oldsymbol{x})^{T} oldsymbol{d} + rac{1}{2} oldsymbol{d}^{T} abla^{2} f( oldsymbol{x}) oldsymbol{d} + o(\lVert oldsymbol{d} Vert^{2}). \]

docs.title: 二次型的界（Bounds on quadratic forms）
docs.text:
对称矩阵 \(\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}\) 满足

\[ \lambda_{\min}\, \lVert \boldsymbol{x} \rVert_2^{2} \;\le\; \boldsymbol{x}^{T} \boldsymbol{A}\, \boldsymbol{x} \;\le\; \lambda_{\max}\, \lVert \boldsymbol{x} \rVert_2^{2}, \qquad \forall\, \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}, \]

其中 \(\lambda_{\max}\) 和 \(\lambda_{\min}\) 分别是 \(\boldsymbol{A}\) 的最大和最小特征值。

docs.title: 二阶充分条件（Second-order sufficient condition）
docs.text:
若 \(f : \mathbb{R}^{n} \to \mathbb{R}\) 二阶连续可微，并且 \(\boldsymbol{x}^{*}\) 是 \(f\) 的一个局部极小点，则其 Hessian 矩阵 \(\boldsymbol{\nabla}^{2} f(\boldsymbol{x}^{*})\) 必为半正定矩阵，即

\[ \boldsymbol{d}^{T}\, \boldsymbol{\nabla}^{2} f(\boldsymbol{x}^{*})\, \boldsymbol{d} \;\ge\; 0, \quad \forall\, \boldsymbol{d} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}. \]

docs.text:
